title: 106_hr5015
content: The Act is titled the "National Student Dropout Prevention and Recovery Act of 2000". Congress acknowledges the challenges of lowering the student dropout rate, citing the lack of federal focus and resources hindering local educational agencies. The National Dropout Prevention Network emphasizes the importance of local efforts in improving schools and increasing graduation rates. Efforts to increase graduation rates should focus on strategies like systemic renewal, community collaboration, professional development, family involvement, early childhood education, reading and writing programs, individualized instruction, instructional technologies, mentoring and tutoring, service learning, learning styles, violence prevention, career education, and workforce readiness. The National Dropout Prevention Network has found that strategies for dropout prevention have been successful in all school levels and settings. Developing model programs based on effective strategies is crucial for schools nationwide to implement similar programs. A nationwide dropout prevention program should be based on successful model programs to lower dropout rates. These programs need to be disseminated to school and community leaders for adaptation and support. SEC. 3. SCHOOL DROPOUT PREVENTION GRANT PROGRAMS. Part C of title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include the Model School Dropout Prevention Grant Program under Subpart 1. SEC. 5311 authorizes this program. The Model School Dropout Prevention Grant Program, authorized by SEC. 5311, awards grants to public schools for dropout prevention programs, research, and assistance to other schools. Grants are awarded for up to 5 years, and schools must reapply for continued funding under the national grant program in SEC. 5312. The Model School Dropout Prevention Grant Program, authorized by SEC. 5311, awards grants to public schools for dropout prevention programs. Schools must use the grant to establish or further develop prevention, intervention, and recovery programs, including various activities like community participation, professional development, early childhood education, mentoring, and career education. The application process and selection of schools are outlined in SEC. 5313. Each school applying for a grant under section 5311 must submit an application to the Director through the local educational agency, detailing their current dropout prevention program. The Director may award grants to a maximum of 20 schools that have shown success in implementing activities outlined in section 5312. Grants under section 5311 are allocated to schools meeting specific requirements, including elementary schools with early childhood education programs, secondary schools with academic intervention and mediation programs, secondary schools with intervention and recovery programs, and schools in rural districts showing success in implementing activities from section 5312. The Director gives priority to schools in urban districts that have successfully implemented activities from section 5312 when awarding grants under section 5311. The local educational agency acts as the fiscal agent for the school and administers the grant, with funds being spent at the school level. The Director of the Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion will award grants to public schools for implementing effective dropout prevention programs lasting 2 to 5 years. A school receiving a grant under section 5321 must use the funds to establish or enhance dropout prevention, intervention, and recovery programs. Activities may include systemic renewal, community involvement, professional development, early childhood education, alternative schooling, mentoring, violence prevention, career education, and a comprehensive dropout prevention plan. Application and selection of schools will be overseen by the Director of the Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion. The Director oversees the application and selection process for schools seeking grants under section 5321. Criteria for awarding grants are based on dropout rates, quality of prevention programs, student demographics, and academic performance. The local educational agency of the school acts as the fiscal agent for the grant awarded under section 5321, with funds to be expended at the school level. SEC. 5331 requires schools receiving grants under section 5311 or 5321 to provide information and assistance to other schools in their district and state. SEC. 5332 outlines the calculation of school dropout rates. SEC. 5332 outlines the calculation of school dropout rates using different methods as determined by the National Center for Education Statistics or the State agency. SEC. 5333 requires schools receiving funding under subpart 1 or 2 to report annually on the implementation of activities funded and provide certification of progress. The Director evaluates the impact of these activities on school dropout prevention compared to a control group. The Director must establish a national clearinghouse on school dropout prevention, intervention, and reentry programs within 6 months of this part's enactment. The clearinghouse will collect and share information on effective programs, best practices, and available resources through various means like databases, websites, and journals. The Director must establish a national clearinghouse on school dropout prevention, intervention, and reentry programs. The clearinghouse will provide technical assistance and professional development opportunities for educators and program providers. "SEC. 5351. Definitions." In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as Director, intervention programs, prevention programs, and recovery programs related to dropout prevention and program completion in schools. Dropout recovery programs are designed to offer schooling options to individuals who have dropped out of school. The term 'school dropout' is defined in the School-to-Work Opportunities Act of 1994. Authorization of appropriations is provided for different subparts for fiscal years 2001 and beyond. Additionally, the establishment of the Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion is outlined in Title II of the Department of Education Organization Act. The Department of Education will establish an Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion to coordinate efforts to reduce school dropout rates and increase program completion for students. The Director of the Office will report to the Under Secretary of Education and recommend policies to achieve these goals. The Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion will prioritize lowering school dropout rates and increasing program completion. The Director will oversee implementation of relevant parts of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, prepare annual national reports, recommend actions to the Secretary and President, and assist State and local governments in dropout prevention efforts. The scope of duties includes examining all Federal and non-Federal efforts related to dropout prevention and program completion. The Director of the Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion will examine Federal and non-Federal efforts related to promoting program completion for children in school, obtaining secondary school diplomas, and reentry programs for individuals aged 12 to 24 who are out of school. The Director may request personnel from Federal departments to be detailed to implement the National School Dropout Prevention Strategy. The Education Organization Act is amended to include a new item after section 217. The Education Organization Act is amended to include a new section, "Office of Dropout Prevention and Program Completion" (Sec. 218).
